“I don’t believe in a future life,” Raskolnikov said. 

Svidrigaïlov sat lost in thought. 

“What if there are only spiders there?” he asked suddenly. 

Raskolnikov felt a chill. “He is a madman,” he thought. 

“Eternity could be a small, grimy room,” Svidrigaïlov mused. 

“Can you imagine nothing juster?” Raskolnikov cried, anguish in his voice. 

“Perhaps that is just,” Svidrigaïlov replied, smiling vaguely. 

Raskolnikov shivered. 

“Only think,” Svidrigaïlov laughed, “we were enemies half an hour ago.” 

“Birds of a feather?” Raskolnikov asked, bewildered.

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Raskolnikov and Svidrigaïlov engage in a philosophical discussion about the nature of eternity and the afterlife, revealing their contrasting beliefs.
